rating_criteria.description: Hypertension is rated based on blood pressure readings and medication requirements

levels.criteria: Diastolic pressure predominantly 100 or more, OR systolic pressure predominantly 160 or more, OR minimum evaluation for individual with history of diastolic pressure predominantly 100 or more who requires continuous medication for control
Diastolic pressure predominantly 110 or more, OR systolic pressure predominantly 200 or more

key_definitions.diastolic_pressure: The bottom number - pressure when heart rests between beats
key_definitions.systolic_pressure: The top number - pressure when heart beats
key_definitions.predominantly: The majority of readings show this level; not just one isolated reading
key_definitions.hypertensive_heart_disease: When hypertension causes heart damage, rated under separate code 7007

blood_pressure_testing.requirement: At least TWO blood pressure readings taken on the day of exam
blood_pressure_testing.additional_readings: Three or more readings on at least two different days if possible
blood_pressure_testing.historical_review: Review of treatment records for blood pressure history
blood_pressure_testing.note: Predominantly means the majority of readings, not just exam day readings

important_evidence: History of blood pressure readings over time
Records showing blood pressure was 'predominantly' at certain levels
Evidence of end-organ damage (heart, kidney, eyes)

secondary_conditions.description: Hypertension can cause or be caused by other conditions

hypertension_as_secondary_to.connection: Sleep apnea is associated with hypertension
Chronic stress from PTSD may contribute to hypertension
Weight gain from psychiatric meds can cause hypertension

conditions_secondary_to_hypertension.connection: Hypertension is a leading cause of kidney disease
High blood pressure can damage eye blood vessels

agent_orange.applies_to: Veterans exposed to Agent Orange or other herbicides
agent_orange.note: Added to presumptive list - no nexus letter required for exposed veterans

camp_lejeune.applies_to: Veterans who served at Camp Lejeune for 30+ days between Aug 1953 and Dec 1987
camp_lejeune.note: Hypertension is one of the Camp Lejeune presumptive conditions

tips_for_veterans: Track your blood pressure at home and bring logs to exam
Document ALL blood pressure medications with dosages
Bring records showing blood pressure history over time
Mention any hypertensive emergencies or crises
Report if blood pressure is uncontrolled despite medication
Document any end-organ damage (heart, kidney, eye problems)
If secondary to another condition, get a nexus letter
Request multiple readings during exam if first reading is low
Don't take extra medication before exam - be honest about control
Mention if you have 'white coat hypertension' affecting readings
common_mistakes: Not having enough blood pressure readings to show 'predominantly' elevated
Taking extra medication before exam which lowers readings
Failing to claim as secondary to diabetes or other conditions
Not reporting complications or end-organ damage
Not knowing about Agent Orange presumptive connection

10_percent_medication_note.criteria: History of diastolic pressure predominantly 100+ WHO REQUIRES continuous medication for control
10_percent_medication_note.explanation: Even if current readings are controlled, you can get 10% if you needed medication to achieve control
10_percent_medication_note.evidence_needed: Medical records showing diastolic was 100+ before medication started

important_notes: Hypertension is presumptive for Agent Orange exposure (as of 2021)
Hypertension is presumptive for Camp Lejeune water contamination
'Predominantly' means majority of readings, not just exam day
Controlled hypertension with medication can still warrant 10%
Hypertensive heart disease (7007) is rated separately from hypertension (7101)
Secondary to diabetes is a very common and valid claim pathway
Multiple blood pressure readings over time are more persuasive than single reading
